content:
A lot of new theory:
https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/11689
It starts with a definition of expressive power of VCSP, proceeds with lemmas about it, and culminates in a proof that, if a VCSP template can express Max-Cut, then it cannot have any commutative fractional polymorphism.

Who will have time to review it?
Perhaps a reasonable candidate for a separate project?

VCSP theory as a separate project is here:
https://github.com/madvorak/vcsp
You mean you don't want me to upstream it to Mathlib?
I don't not want you to upstream it. More I would like to work out what good criteria are for deciding whether such projects should be in Mathlib or out.

I think a good rule of thumb is: "if there isn't an expert reviewer available, then it shouldn't go in Mathlib!". And more formally, I hope we can evolve from "everything belongs in Mathlib" to "there is a reasonable expectation that more than one other person will later want to build on this".
Sorry --- this conversation shouldn't be happening here on your PR, it was a mistake to try and start such a discussion locally. I don't want to single out your project / PR.

I was intending it to be in Mathlib from the beginning. Therefore, I created my VCSP repo only as a buffer for things that have been implemented but haven't been upstreamed to Mathlib yet (if something was staying in my repo for a longer time without a Mathlib PR, it was because I was not sure about a certain definition and I wanted to wait before I set it into stone).

This approach was a reaction to my previous experience, when I developed the theory of grammars completely outside of Mathlib and, when the time for contributing to Mathlib came, it had diverged too far from what Mathlib wanted.

However, if Mathlib doesn't want to have VCSP at all, it is a very different situation. I thought VCSP theory was naturally highly general and thus suitable for Mathlib, but I might have been wrong.
I think this needs wider discussion, but I can see the point that in order to keep mathlib maintainable, we need people who can review large new additions - preferably more than one
It's not something I'd ever heard of, but of course it's far from my corner of maths. This is why "exhibit a reviewer" seems like a good criterion.
How about we pause here, and restart this conversation afresh elsewhere?

Scott Morrison said:

How about we pause here, and restart this conversation afresh elsewhere?

-> https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/VCSP.20theory
Ah -- I intended "restart a conversation about the abstract scope, regarding areas with few or no reviewers, without mentioning VCSP". :-)
